case.title: SRC International Trial (RM42 Million)
case.subtitle: Najib Razak's First 1MDB-Related Conviction
case.description: The SRC International trial was the first of several 1MDB-related cases against former Prime Minister Najib Razak. SRC International Sdn Bhd, a former subsidiary of 1MDB, was established to invest in energy resources but became central to corruption charges. Najib faced 7 counts: 1 count of abuse of power under Section 23 of the MACC Act 2009 for approving RM4 billion in loans from KWAP to SRC International, 3 counts of criminal breach of trust under Section 409 of the Penal Code, and 3 counts of money laundering under Section 4(1)(b) of AMLA 2001 involving RM42 million that flowed into his personal bank accounts.
case.verdictSummary: Najib Razak was found guilty on all 7 charges. He was sentenced to 12 years imprisonment and fined RM210 million (in default, 5 years imprisonment). The conviction was upheld by the Court of Appeal in December 2021 and the Federal Court in August 2022. His application for a royal pardon and home detention was denied.
case.metaDescription: Complete coverage of Najib Razak's SRC International trial - the landmark Malaysian corruption case involving RM42 million. Timeline, lawyers, verdict, and appeal history.

timeline.title: Charged at Kuala Lumpur Sessions Court
timeline.description: Najib Razak was charged with 7 counts at the Kuala Lumpur Sessions Court: 1 count of abuse of power under Section 23 of the MACC Act 2009, 3 counts of criminal breach of trust under Section 409 of the Penal Code, and 3 counts of money laundering under AMLA 2001. He pleaded not guilty to all charges.

timeline.title: Trial Begins at High Court
timeline.description: The trial commenced at the Kuala Lumpur High Court before Justice Mohd Nazlan Mohd Ghazali. The prosecution was led by Senior Deputy Public Prosecutor Gopal Sri Ram.

timeline.title: First Witness Testifies
timeline.description: AmBank relationship manager Joanna Yu testified about the opening of Najib's personal accounts and the flow of funds from SRC International.

timeline.title: Prima Facie Case Established
timeline.description: Justice Nazlan ruled that the prosecution had established a prima facie case on all 7 charges. Najib was called to enter his defence.

timeline.title: Defense Case Begins
timeline.description: Najib's defense case commenced. Lead defense counsel Muhammad Shafee Abdullah outlined the defense strategy.

timeline.title: Najib Testifies in Own Defense
timeline.description: Najib took the stand as the first defense witness. He testified that he believed the funds in his accounts were donations from the Saudi royal family, not from SRC International.

timeline.title: Verdict: Guilty on All 7 Charges
timeline.description: Justice Nazlan found Najib guilty on all 7 charges. He was sentenced to 12 years imprisonment and fined RM210 million. Execution of sentence was stayed pending appeal.

timeline.title: Appeal Filed
timeline.description: Najib filed an appeal against his conviction and sentence at the Court of Appeal.

timeline.title: Appeal Hearing Begins
timeline.description: The appeal hearing commenced before a three-member Court of Appeal panel led by Justice Abdul Karim Abdul Jalil.

timeline.title: Court of Appeal Upholds Conviction
timeline.description: The Court of Appeal unanimously upheld Najib's conviction and 12-year sentence. The panel found no merit in the grounds of appeal.

timeline.title: Leave to Appeal to Federal Court Granted
timeline.description: The Federal Court granted Najib leave to appeal on specific legal questions regarding the trial judge and prosecution conduct.

timeline.title: Federal Court Dismisses Final Appeal
timeline.description: A five-member Federal Court panel led by Chief Justice Tengku Maimun Tuan Mat unanimously dismissed Najib's final appeal. Najib began serving his 12-year prison sentence at Kajang Prison.

timeline.title: Pardons Board Reduces Sentence
timeline.description: The Pardons Board reduced Najib's prison sentence from 12 years to 6 years and his fine from RM210 million to RM50 million. His application for house arrest was denied.
